question: We spent some time together.
answer: Why do I get the feeling when you say some time, you mean some time.

question: I was already here a good many years when they came in in 1932.
answer: 1932? That's like, that's like...

question: Oh, no, Ray. Not tonight. Spanky's not happy with you.
answer: Is Spanky here?

question: No, but...
answer: Then what's the problem?

question: Do yourself a favor and find another place where they let you in the front door.
answer: But this is where the action is and I have to be where the action is. Look, when your old lady wanted those alligator shoes, didn't I come through for you? Ain't she stepping in style now?

question: Yeah...
answer: Well, alright then. What do you think about this new tie?

question: Sharp.
answer: I look good tonight. And I feel lucky, too.

question: Anyone asks, it wasn't me who let you in.
answer: When do you get off? I sure can't drink that watered-down swill you're serving. Give me a glass of ice.

question: For the kind of money they charge here, you'd think they could hire somebody to actually wash the dishes.
answer: Claude. Here's to your new job down at the bank. I always knew you'd make something of yourself.

question: Know what I'm going to buy with my first pay check? Season tickets to the Yankees. Right there on the first base line. What's wrong, baby?
answer: I was hoping you were gonna say an engagement ring, Claude.

question: Engagement ring!
answer: That's what respectable folks do. Get a job, get married, start having babies. That's what you want, isn't it?

question: Sure it is. I just don't see any reason to rush into things. Damn, look at this shirt. I'll be right back. Now wait a second, guys. I've got a bill to pay out there. Come on, fellas, that's two weeks pay. I'm here with my girl. You gotta leave me something. My legs? Those are good, I'll keep the legs...
answer: You have any of that French stuff? Keep the change. Don't I know you?

question: I don't think so.
answer: Sure I do. What's your name again?

question: Claude Banks.
answer: Claude Banks. How could I forget that? You've got to remember me. Ray Gibson. We went to high school together.

question: You went to Monroe?
answer: That's right! Good old Monroe...

question: Well, I went to Jefferson, so you must have a different Claude Banks in mind.
answer: Sorry, man. My mistake. Watch the threads, Bullethead. If this is about my tab, I've got it covered.

question: The bill. Of course, the bill. We couldn't leave without paying the bill. Especially such an incredibly large bill.
answer: Save your energy, Claude. You're gonna need it. Here, this belongs to you. It was empty when I found it.

question: Good old Monroe.
answer: What I want to know is what happened to your cush between the time that you got up from the table and when I caught up with you in the Johnny?

question: I don't see where that's any of your business.
answer: Did those two muscle heads shake you down? Swear I've seen them down at the track with Sure-shot Riley. That's it, ain't it? A gambling debt.

question: Where they taking us, anyway?
answer: Probably to Spanky's headquarters down at the pier.

question: Good, I'm looking forward to meeting this Spanky. Give me a chance to straighten out this whole mess.
answer: I can't wait to see that. You slay me, man.

question: What are they gonna do to us?
answer: You? Dine and ditch, right? Over ten bucks? You're probably looking at a thumb.

question: A thumb? What do you mean, like cut it off? For ten bucks? That include the tip?
answer: You picked the wrong night to fuck with me, Ray. I just lost three men and a truck full of Canadian whiskey. You know what that kind of thing does to my business? It makes me want to lash out and hurt somebody. Who's he? Friend of yours, Ray?

question: I never saw this man before tonight. He's a lowlife degenerate who lurks in bathrooms. I'm a professional man, an upstanding citizen. I go to church on Sunday.
answer: Then what are you doing here?

question: Look, Mr. Johnson, you seem like a reasonable man. I got a good job starts Monday. I'll pay you back with my first pay check. With interest. I don't want to tell you how to conduct your business, but if you cut off my finger you won't get jack. Working an adding machine, I gotta be whole. I need my thumbs and all my fingers for praying and doing good...
answer: The choirboy wants to keep his fingers. Who am I to argue? Drop him.

question: Drop him? What does drop him mean?
answer: You gotta lotta balls showing your face around my club. If a man's gonna run numbers on my side of Broadway, you think he'd have the common sense to keep a low profile. But not Ray Gibson.

question: What's that, some of your bathtub brew?
answer: Puerto Rican rum. See for yourself.

question: Where'd you get this?
answer: Comes up the Mississippi. I can get more. A lot more. I was thinking about going into business for myself, but under the circumstances, I'd be willing to take on a partner.

question: I'm interested. Keep talking.
answer: All I need is the front money and a truck. I could be back in two, three days tops if I had somebody to share the driving.

question: If you fuck me on this one, I'll spare no expense.
answer: Understood.

question: Alright, Ray, you've got a deal. Pick your man and get going.
answer: I'll take the little choirboy, if you don't mind.

question: If I was you, I'd want somebody who can handle himself in a tight spot.
answer: I just want somebody who won't put a bullet in my back once the truck is full.

question: For your sake, I hope you can drive. Somebody give him some dry clothes.
answer: Tell me about that hot sketch you were hypin' last night. She was a choice bit of calico. You two been seeing each other a long time? Gonna slap the handcuffs on her and stroll down the aisle one of these days? Sometimes I wish I could find me a sheba to settle down with. Suppose I'm just a tomcat by nature. This little rum run is gonna seriously improve my relationship with Spanky. He's a good man to have on your side. He's got the capital and the connections. That's what you got to have in that business. Spanky's place is pretty plush, but one of these days I'm gonna open up my own establishment. Ray's Boom-Boom Room. You like that? Ray's Boom-Boom Room. That's in the groove, don't you think? Come on, daddy-o. You haven't said a word since we started. Least you could do is make some friendly conversation.

question: Tell me about that hot sketch you were hypin' last night. She was a choice bit of calico. You two been seeing each other a long time? Gonna slap the handcuffs on her and stroll down the aisle one of these days? Sometimes I wish I could find me a sheba to settle down with. Suppose I'm just a tomcat by nature. This little rum run is gonna seriously improve my relationship with Spanky. He's a good man to have on your side. He's got the capital and the connections. That's what you got to have in that business. Spanky's place is pretty plush, but one of these days I'm gonna open up my own establishment. Ray's Boom-Boom Room. You like that? Ray's Boom-Boom Room. That's in the groove, don't you think? Come on, daddy-o. You haven't said a word since we started. Least you could do is make some friendly conversation.
answer: Look, man, I don't want friendly conversation. I don't want to be your friend. I've seen your friends and I don't like them. I just want to do this thing and get back to New York in time to start my job.

question: Start your job? What kind of job?
answer: Well, if you must know, bank teller at First Federal of Manhattan. I'm responsible for keeping track of hundreds, occasionally thousands of dollars.

question: That's some long green.
answer: Damn straight, it is. I got my own set of keys because I'm supposed to open up. So if I ain't there 8 a.m. Monday morning, there's gonna be hell to pay. What?

question: Nothing.
answer: No, tell me what's so funny.

question: I don't know. Bank teller. Sounds like ladies work to me.
answer: Well, maybe I should dig around in other people's clothes for money. It's obviously been highly successful for you.

question: Hey, you'd be surprised what you find in other people's pockets. Just gotta avoid them deadbeat bank tellers. Get you every time.
answer: I didn't start out to be a bank teller. I was gonna be a ballplayer. Even had an offer to play short for the Newark Eagles.

question: Why didn't you take it?
answer: The Negro League don't pay so good. And you're always on the road. That don't wash with Daisy.

question: You gave up baseball to be a bank teller? I can't latch on to that.
answer: At some point a man's got to get serious about his future. I'm sure you have no idea what I'm talking about.

question: You're talking about giving up baseball to be a bank teller.
answer: Bank teller's just a start. I got plans. Real plans. Not opening some Zoom-Boom Room. This time next year I'll be a loan officer.

question: A loan officer?
answer: That's right, a loan officer.

question: So you mean, if I needed some jack to get my nightclub up and running, I'd have to hype some square like you?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: How would I get a loan, anyway?
answer: You need collateral.

question: Like this?
answer: That thing? Who'd you steal it from?

question: My daddy gave me this watch.
answer: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from?

question: My daddy is dead so watch your mouth. You can say what you want about me, but don't be dragging my daddy into it. This watch means the world to me. Solid gold. Keeps perfect time.
answer: Looks like a fake to me. Loan denied!

question: Ah, go chase yourself. I'll take my business elsewhere. And for future reference, you are no longer welcome at Ray's Boom-Boom Room.
answer: There is no Boom-Boom Room.

question: When there is, you can forget about it. And I swear to God, you ever talk about my daddy again I'm gonna kick your bank-telling, loan-denying ass, you got me?
answer: Oooh...

question: I think I liked you better when you kept your trap shut. Man, something smells good in here. How's everybody doing?
answer: Maybe we oughta find another place.

question: Are you kidding? Tell me you don't want a slice of that pie right over there.
answer: I must have left my appetite outside, which is where I think we ought to be right now.

question: Good evening, Billy. We'd like some coffee and a couple of slices of that homemade pie you've got advertised. It says so right there on your shirt.
answer: You mean this sign? The one that says "No Coloreds Allowed." That's a good question. Ray, how come we missed the sign?

question: Look, ma'am, we've been driving all day. We'd just like to purchase one of those pies and we'll be on our way. Got any nigger pies?
answer: Any fool could see those are whites- only, not-for-blacks, come-on-let's- get-the-fuck-outta-here pies. Thank you very much.

question: Thanks for backing me up here, Uncle Claude.
answer: Don't Uncle Claude me. You get a load of those crackers? Couldn't be a mouthful of teeth among the bunch of 'em. Why you want to pick a fight with people like that for?

question: You're soft.
answer: What'd you say?

question: I said you're soft.
answer: Hey, man, don't ever call me that.

question: I call it like I see it, and what I see is definitely soft.
answer: Alright. You want some pie?

question: Yeah, I want some pie.
answer: Okay then, I'm gonna walk over to that counter and get us some fucking pie. Excuse me, ma'am, I bet a brick will turn that one right there into a colored pie. Okay, Ray, I think we can go now. Much obliged...

question: How you doing? We're looking for Slim. Man, that music is hot. What goes on down there, Slim? Blacks welcome there? Maybe we will. Nice meeting you.
answer: Nice meeting you? You've been here before, haven't you?

question: What gave you that idea?
answer: Oh, I don't know, maybe because our lives depend on it, I just sort of thought you knew what you were doing!

question: Don't get all agitated on me. I bought a bottle of rum from a couple of dudes, I heard 'em talking...
answer: Let me get this straight. We drove all the way down to Klan country 'cause you heard a couple of guys talking?

question: What are you complaining about? It worked out. Everything's cool. Now, come on, let's head down there and see what's shaking. We deserve a little reward.
answer: Reward?

question: There are people down there having fun. I want to be one of them. I want you to be one of them. On Monday you can be a bank teller if you want, but tonight you're a bootlegger with a truck full of Puerto Rican rum and a fistful of cash.
answer: That's gas money.

question: There's your gas money. You stay here and watch the truck. And don't worry, I've got the keys.
answer: I'm just gonna keep an eye on you, make sure you don't do nothing stupid.

question: I'm just gonna keep an eye on you, make sure you don't do nothing stupid.
answer: I've never seen you in here before.

question: That's because I've never been here before.
answer: I'm Sylvia. What's your name? Can't you remember your own name?

question: I know it begins with a "C"...
answer: Well, Mr. "C", how about buying a girl a drink? Two bourbons.

question: I really shouldn't. I gotta keep an eye on my friend.
answer: He looks like he can take care of himself.

question: Claude. That's my name. Claude. That's never happened before.
answer: You're cute. You have any money, Claude?

question: Ten dollars. But I need it to get home.
answer: Why would you want to go home? It's so early.

question: I'll take two.
answer: I'll see that... And while we're at it, let's sweeten the pot.

question: Looks like my sugar bowl's empty, Mr. Hancock.
answer: That's just too damn bad, ain't it?

question: Now, hang on, slick. I ain't through with you yet.
answer: That'll cover it.

question: Full boat, ladies doing the paddling.
answer: Four threes. Don't take it too hard, New York. Have a round on me.

question: Hey, Ray. I've been looking for you.
answer: Here I am.

question: Guess we better get going, huh?
answer: Still got that ten dollars?

question: Well, not exactly. See, I met this girl. Real nice girl. God-fearing girl. Her name's Sylvia.
answer: That jelly you were talking to right here?

question: She's in a tight spot. Her mama needs this operation, and they ain't got the money for it. Their church took up a collection but they were still short...
answer: So you made a generous contribution.

question: What can I say? When the spirit moves me.
answer: That was mighty charitable of you, Claude. Looks like we both got fucked tonight.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: While you were upstairs doing God's work, I was getting jack-legged by a fool with four threes.

question: You lost all our money in a card game?
answer: He even got my daddy's watch.

question: Fuck that cheap-ass watch -- I mean, how the hell are we gonna get home without any money?
answer: We've still got 36 cases of rum. That's better than money.

question: You sure the truck's this way? I swear it was back that way. Ray... Yo, Ray...! I think he's hurt pretty bad.
answer: He's dead.

question: Oh, man, I've never seen a dead body before! What do you think you're doing?! The man's been dead for two seconds! Don't you have any respect?
answer: It ain't here.

question: What ain't there?
answer: My daddy's watch. This is the dude I was telling you about --

question: Afraid not.
answer: Mr. Johnson is very well connected. If you were to let us go, I guarantee he would show you his appreciation, if you know what I mean.

question: Are you offering me a bribe?
answer: I'm just trying to pay the toll on the road to justice.

question: He says it's too hot, boss.
answer: Too hot, huh? Well, you tell that lazy jiggaboo the state of Mississippi ain't interested in his meteorological assessments.

question: Listen up, jiggaboo! State of Mississippi ain't interested in your... in your... metropolitan assets!
answer: Tell him the state of Mississippi is only interested in getting this ditch cleared by sundown.

question: I don't even know who this is from.
answer: Here, gimme that. It's from your mama's neighbor, Mrs. Tidwell. She thought you oughta know that your second cousin Bo died. And your other cousin, Sally, on your daddy's side, she died. Apparently, your sister died.

question: Jenny?
answer: No, it says Marleen here. Oh, wait, looks like Jenny died, too. Then it goes on for a while about how the crop didn't come in on accounta the frost. She finishes up with something about a tornado and how your mama and your daddy died in that. But don't worry none. She'll take care of the dog. That is, if it gets over the worms.

question: Appreciate it.
answer: Anybody else need anything read?

question: How you doin'?
answer: I'm all right.

question: You ever done time before?
answer: You kidding? I've been in and out of prison my entire life. Mostly in. I'm hard-core.

question: Then you won't have no problem making the adjustment. You need anything, help of any kind, gimme a holler. Name's Jangle Leg.
answer: 'Preciate it. Claude.

question: Soft and supple. Like a lady's.
answer: I try to moisturize regularly.

question: Mama?
answer: Rayford!

question: What are you doing here, mama?
answer: I heard some things so I went to see Spanky Johnson. He told me what happened and gave me some money to get down here. What happened to your face?

question: Yeah...
answer: This is a big surprise, mama. I sure didn't expect to see you down here.

question: Rayford, I wanted so much more for you than this.
answer: Don't cry, mama. This place ain't so bad as it looks. Sure, we work hard, but there's plenty fresh air and sunshine... And you know something else, I've taken to going to church regular. They got services every Sunday right there in the mess hall.

question: Don't you lie to me, Rayford. You still have your daddy's watch? Well, this is all I can give you. I wish it was more.
answer: I can't take that, mama.

question: Don't argue with me. You need it more than I do. I know how a little money can help in a place like this.
answer: I can't believe this. I always said I'd never end up like this. I thought I'd make something of myself, do something with my life. You know, be successful. Have a big house, a family. Now I'm gonna end up just like daddy.

question: Don't say that, Rayford. Don't ever say that. He gave up hope. That's where you gotta be different.
answer: They gave me life, mama.

question: Woman came all the way from New York, goddamnit! We'll come out when we're good and ready! Did you go see my cousin Maynard like I asked you in my letter?
answer: Of course I did. He said he'd file an appeal right away. You didn't tell me he was so good looking.

question: Yeah, that side of the family has all the looks and none of the brains. I hope he don't mess things up.
answer: He seemed like a pretty good lawyer to me. His offices take up an entire floor of that big, new building on 125th Street, and he was using all these words I never heard before. He even offered me a job.

question: A job, huh? Well, that's nice, real nice. You won't have to work long. I'll be back soon enough. After I start work at First Federal Bank of Manhattan, I'll be keeping you in style. Everything will get back to normal again. That's a promise.
answer: Listen, Claude, Maynard wanted to know if he should file the appeal on behalf of your friend, too.

question: Ray Gibson? No, no. He's the reason I'm in here, Daisy. For all I know, he's got a record a mile long. I got a better shot of getting out of here on my own. You tell Maynard to think about me, concentrate on me. Understand?
answer: Sure, Claude, whatever you say.

question: Cookie drew me a map to Greenville.
answer: So?

question: You know what I'm saying.
answer: Yeah, I know what your saying. And I'm saying if you made it that far, they'd be watching every train that pulls out of that station.

question: That's why we won't take the train. Cookie showed me where there's a farm house. They got a boat there.
answer: What do you know about boats? I bet you can't even swim.

question: What I know about boats is they take you to freedom. Come on, man. I think we can do this.
answer: Why are you always talking about we? There is no we. There is a me, there is a you. But there is no we between us.

question: You want out of this place, don't you? Don't tell me you're starting to like it here.
answer: No, I don't like it here. Look around. There's nothing but ass. Male ass! Balls and ass! Believe you me, I'm getting out of here.

question: What does that mean?
answer: Forget it.

question: I'm not gonna forget it. What does that mean? If you've got a plan, I think I have a right to know about it. I told you my plan.
answer: Getting a map from a chubby chef named Cookie? Dragging our asses through the swamps in search of some worm-eaten boat? That ain't a plan, that's a vacation for two in the hole. When you've got a map to New York City, you get back to me.

question: Here!
answer: Maynard Banks, Esquire. Attorney at law.

question: Gimme that. That doesn't concern you.
answer: I'm sure it don't.

question: What's up, Ray?
answer: Claude.

question: Sure is hot today. Think it'll rain later?
answer: What do you want, Claude?

question: What do I want? What makes you think I want something?
answer: My daddy always said when a man starts talking about the weather keep you hand on your wallet.

question: Your daddy must have been a helluva guy, a deep man, a wise man. Sure wish I could have met him --
answer: Cut the bullshit. What do you want, Claude?

question: You still got that map?
answer: Yeah.

question: Well, if you're still thinking about booking it, I want in. I think we can make it.
answer: We? Did I hear you say we? As I recall, you're the one who said there is no we. Guess we got some bad news in that letter, huh?

question: Look, my cousin Maynard is a lawyer. He filed an appeal on my behalf --
answer: On your behalf. What happened to we?

question: The appeal was denied. Then Daisy went and fell for Maynard. They're engaged to be married, can you believe that?
answer: Well, let's just think about that for a moment. He's a successful lawyer up in New York City and you're down here with a bright future in the cotton picking business. Eeny, meeny, miney, Maynard.

question: Come on, man. Don't shut me out. I'm telling you, you and me, that map, we can go places.
answer: You know what, Claude? This whole time we've been down here, you've done nothing but think about yourself, acting like this whole thing is my fault. That plan with your cousin, did that include me?

question: No.
answer: At least you're honest for once. So now you want to be my friend? Well, let me tell you something, Claude-my- shit-don't-stink-Banks. You got a lot to learn about friendship.

question: Does that mean I'm in?
answer: I don't think so, Claude. You'd just slow me down. We'd have to stop every five minutes so you could polish your silverware. There's no way around it, you're soft.

question: What'd you say?
answer: I said you're soft.

question: You did it, man! You got us out! Next stop, New York City!
answer: New York's a long way's off. Let's just keep moving, okay?

question: I know these trees all look the same, but I'm getting an awful familiar vibration from this one right here. You sure you know where we're going?
answer: Absolutely. The map is very clear.

question: Let me take a look at that map. You call this a map? What was Cookie smoking when he drew this?
answer: Cookie didn't draw it. I did.

question: You drew this?!
answer: I knew you wouldn't come if I didn't have a map.

question: Claude? You alright?!
answer: Can't take it no more, Ray! Die, motherfucker! Gotta get the fuck outta here!

question: Keep it together, Claude. You wake up the man, he'll shoot you for sure.
answer: He'd be doing me a favor. I'm getting outta here one way or the other! Goddamn rats and shit! Fuck!

question: All right, man, just settle down. We'll get outta here, Claude. We'll get outta here real soon.
answer: How the fuck are we gonna do that, Ray?!

question: We'll just get off at the next stop.
answer: Say what?

question: That's right, we'll get off at the next stop. The train's pulling into the station right now.
answer: The hell you talking about? What train?

question: We're in the Bronx, my man. Hundred and Sixty First Street.
answer: Hundred and Sixty First Street? That's Yankee Stadium.

question: Hell, yes, Yankee Stadium. Bombers are playing a double-header against the Red Sox.
answer: Red Sox... Who's on the mound?

question: I don't know. Who do you want?
answer: Allie Reynolds. He's my boy.

question: Sure, it says Allie Reynolds right here in the program. He's warming up right now. Man, we're so close to the field I need cleats. How'd you get such good seats?
answer: I know people.

question: They must be the right people. Whoa, there goes the hot dog man. Let's get a couple. Damn, that smells good. Nothing like a ballpark hot dog, huh?
answer: You get ketchup?

question: Ketchup? Who eats ketchup on a hot dog? Mustard's what you want.
answer: I can't eat it with mustard.

question: Give me back that hot dog. I'll eat it myself.
answer: What am I gonna eat?

question: You can starve to death for all I care. Now shut up, the game's about to start.
answer: Hey, man, is Babe Ruth in the lineup today?

question: If you step outside the gun line without my permission, you will be shot. If you trip and fall over the gun line, you will be shot. If you spit, if you pee, if you stick your ass out and take a dump over the gun line, you will be shot...
answer: I try to teach 'em the finer points of the game, share my wisdom, but I don't know why I bother. They don't listen, they sure don't learn...

question: What you're dealing with here is a complete lack of talent.
answer: I'm sick of watching Camp 12 win the championship. Every year they get to roast the victory pig and we get dick. This year I want that pig. Alright, Radio, there you go. Who wants to hit next?

question: You want to hit? Yo, Claude. Give Can't Get Right a shot.
answer: Him?

question: Can't be worse than any of these other fools.
answer: All right, grab the bat. Let's see what you can do. Jangle Leg's gonna throw the ball nice and easy. You just go ahead and take a swing. Okay. Let's try that again. This time give it a little juice.

question: Negro Leagues, actually. Pittsburgh Crawfords. Ever hear of us?
answer: We get the games on the radio sometimes.

question: We played down in Jackson yesterday. Heard a rumor you've got a boy up here who can hit the ball a ton.
answer: You probably mean Can't Get Right. That's him over there.

question: Can't Get Right? That's the kid's name? Can I talk to him?
answer: You can try, but you won't get too far. Why you interested?

question: Crawford's are always looking for new talent.
answer: Maybe you didn't notice, but this is a prison.

question: There are ways around that. Right sergeant? Nice looking squad. See you after the game.
answer: You're my boy, just keep what little mind you have focused on the game. If you hit that ball the way I know you can, you might just be our ticket off this farm.

question: Don't take it so hard, Biscuit. She don't mean nothin' to him.
answer: Hell with him. It ain't that.

question: These are free papers.
answer: What am I gonna do out there, Ray? I can't go home to my mama like this. I'll get the strap for sure.

question: It's 1945. It's a different world now.
answer: Not for me, it ain't.

question: Well you can't stay here, Biscuit. This ain't no life for a man. Any one of these fellas would give their right arm to be in your shoes. I sure know I would.
answer: No life on the inside, no life on the outside...

question: I'm not gonna let it go. The man needs to explain himself. Makin' promises.
answer: Look, I am truly sorry about this. I'd like to help you...

question: But you can't.
answer: At least the kid's getting out. Isn't this what you wanted?

question: One of the new kids said they're farming those acres just north of the swamp. He said he saw a crop duster flying around the place.
answer: I'm not in the mood right now, Ray.

question: He said they keep it parked out behind the barn. Can't be that hard to fly a plane. Lots of people do it.
answer: They're called pilots! I'm serious, Ray. I'm not in the mood for one of your stupid, fucked-up plans right now.

question: I don't see you coming up with any plans.
answer: My plan is on his way to Pittsburgh right now. That congenital idiot just got himself a pardon signed by the governor thanks to us, but we can't seem to do nothing for ourselves. Don't you feel a little disgusted right now?

question: Crop duster.
answer: I ain't getting in no airplane with you. I'm finally wrapping my mind around the concept. They threw us in this shithole for life. Don't you get it, Ray? We're gonna die here! Might as well head up to the cemetery, pick a plot and start digging.

question: My daddy died in prison. He gave up hope and hung himself. What you're talking about is the same damn thing. That ain't how I'm going.
answer: Maybe you're fooling yourself, Ray. Maybe you're just a chip off the old block.

question: Take that back or we ain't friends no more, Claude Banks.
answer: Here's a news flash, Ray. We never were friends. We've just been stuck together for 12 years. It's been nothing but bad luck since the moment I ran into you. Every time I look at you I get sick to my stomach thinking about what my life could have been if I'd never bumped into Ray Gibson.

question: Better watch yourself Claude, before you say something you regret.
answer: The only thing I regret is the day I met you.

question: Well, if that's the way it is...
answer: That's the way it is.

question: Then I have nothing left to say to you.
answer: You never said nothing of value anyway.

question: Are you Claude Banks?
answer: Yeah.

question: My name's Yvette. Sylvia sent me. You look just like she said.
answer: She's alright, isn't she?

question: Oh, she's fine. She's just not coming today.
answer: Why not?

question: She got married last month.
answer: Married?

question: Real nice guy, too. Trumpet player. They moved down to New Orleans. She always said that if you were on the outside...
answer: But I'm not on the outside. I'm in here.

question: I know she's sorry she won't be seeing you anymore. Anyway, she wanted me to take care of you.
answer: Take care of me?

question: You know, go to the tonk or whatever.
answer: I'm too old for you. Besides, I'm not much in the mood.

question: Want me to come back some other time?
answer: Nice girl like you don't belong in a place like this. But if you talk to Sylvia, tell her old Claude said congratulations. Whites-only pies...

question: You don't want to give me a gun, boss. I'm liable to use it on you.
answer: You're a sucker. I'd have taken that deal.

question: Excuse me? Are you talking to me?
answer: I'd have knocked you off those bottles, put a bullet in your ass and be half way to New York right now.

question: After all these years of blissful silence, I almost forgot how annoying the sound of your voice can be.
answer: I hope you don't think I owe you anything. Because I don't owe you a damn thing.

question: I didn't do if for you, anyway. I just ain't no boot-licking trusty, that's all.
answer: I was sorry to hear about your mama passing.

question: That was five years ago.
answer: I know, but since we're talking, I thought I'd mention it.

question: We're not talking, you're talking, and doing too damn much of it, if you ask me.
answer: What?!

question: You sure looked funny running for those pies, bullets flying all around you.
answer: Bullets weren't the problem. That pie was too hot. Burned my tongue.

question: Oh, yard boy, these pansies could use some attention over here. Perhaps some fertilizer would restore their exuberance.
answer: Damn dentures slipping again. Everything falls apart when you grow old, eh, Claude? Time sure marches on.

question: Yes, boss.
answer: You know, I'm fixing on retiring at the end of the summer, gonna try to enjoy what few years I have left. What do you think of this place? It's one of those new retirement communities down on the Gulf.

question: Ocean views, palm trees, two heated swimming pools and a golf course -- sounds a damn sight better than that infirmary across the way where I'm gonna end up.
answer: I apologize, Claude. That was rude of me.

question: That's alright, boss. Takes a lot more than a colorful brochure to hurt my feelings.
answer: You been on the farm for quite a spell, haven't you?

question: Over forty years now. Me and Ray Gibson out there.
answer: Forty years. That's a long time for any crime, even murder.

question: It's a hell of a lot longer when you're innocent.
answer: Half the men in this prison swear they're innocent. Don't you think that's kinda funny?

question: You have to forgive me if I don't laugh.
answer: You and Wilkins sure are getting chummy. You two planning on going steady, or something?

question: He's just a lonely old man. He likes to talk.
answer: Hey, I'm a lonely old man. I like to talk, too. So why don't we start by talking about what kind of a plan you're working on?

question: I'm not working on a plan.
answer: You can't fool me, Claude. I know you got something brewing.

question: Damn, it was getting hot in there.
answer: What the hell are you doing in that trunk?!

question: You didn't think I was gonna let you escape alone, did you?
answer: I ain't escaping! We're picking up the new super just like I told you.

question: Then you're lucky I came along. Doesn't take a visionary to spot a golden opportunity like this. Now help me out of this trunk.
answer: You ain't getting out of that trunk.

question: Come on, man, I'm starting to cramp up here. We have the chance right here, right now, I say we go!
answer: Go where, Ray?

question: Back to New York for starters.
answer: And what will we do when we get there? I'm sixty-five years old, Ray. So are you. What are we gonna do out here? Get married, have kids, settle down? That boat sailed without us, man.

question: This boat's gonna sail without you, too. I don't care if I last one day out here. At least it's one day of freedom. Now gimme those keys.
answer: Forget about that. You run if you want to, but you're not taking this car.

question: Claude, man, I'm serious. Give me those keys.
answer: I ain't spending a month in the hole so you can take a joy ride.

question: Don't make me take them away from you.
answer: Hey, there's Wilkins! Who's driving now, bitch?

question: You sure it was him?
answer: Some faces you just don't forget. Warren Pike's is one of 'em.

question: I don't like it, I don't like it one bit. We shoulda taken that car when we had the opportunity. We'd be half way to New York by now.
answer: We'd be in the hole by now. Hey, man, you're peeing on my shoe.

question: Lemonade?
answer: I prefer bourbon.

question: I'm sorry, I don't keep any liquor in the house.
answer: Well, fortunately, I carry my own.

question: Hunting's been pretty good on the farm the last few years. It's one of the perks of the job. If you're interested, tomorrow I could show you some of my favorite spots.
answer: You don't have to twist my arm. Say now, that gumbo has quite a kick.

question: Goodnight, Claude.
answer: If you don't mind my saying, you seem mighty familiar with your house boy.

question: I believe in treating the convicts with respect, if that's what you mean.
answer: Respect? Well, isn't that progressive.

question: If somebody deserves respect, Mr. Pike, they receive it from me, convict or no convict. Well, that's a pretty good haul. What do you say, Mr. Pike? Ready to call it a day?
answer: Yeah, it's getting late. I could sure use a bath.

question: Yeah, it's getting late. I could sure use a bath.
answer: That's a real nice watch you got there, sir. Fancy old thing even plays a little tune.

question: Yeah, it's special. They don't make 'em like this anymore.
answer: Sure don't. Mind if I ask where you got it?

question: Why, my wife gave it to me on our anniversary some years back.
answer: Must have been some time ago. Maybe forty years?

question: Something like that, yes.
answer: She give you that scar, too?

question: I oughta shoot you for that comment, boy.
answer: Like you shot Winston Hancock?

question: Forty years of cheap labor! Gimme that gun.
answer: No, I'm gonna kill him --

question: No, believe me, I'm gonna kill him! I can't do it.
answer: That's because you're soft. Gimme the gun.

question: What'd you say?
answer: I said you're soft.

question: Don't call me soft, I hate it when you call me that.
answer: I believe this is mine.

question: Nurse Humphries was checking my prostate this morning. I got an erection.
answer: An erection, huh? Haven't had one of those in a while.

question: Tell me about it. Scared me at first. Then, before I could figure out what to do with it, it was gone. Imagine my disappointment.
answer: Sure would like to see the house that Ruth built one more time.

question: Well, Ruth shoulda built it a little better. Damn thing's falling to pieces. Gonna hurt somebody.
answer: What do you expect? It's almost as old as we are.

question: They oughta tear that shit down and ship them Yankees cross the river to Jersey.
answer: Remember what that place looked like on a sunny spring day? More beautiful than any church I was ever in. Looks like old Jonesy finally got his walking papers.

question: Over to the morgue and up the hill to the cemetery. Never thought I'd admit it, Claude, but you were right.
answer: 'Course I was right. About what?

question: You're the one who said that boneyard's the only way we're getting out of here. We're gonna join all the rest of 'em soon enough. Jangle Leg, Biscuit, Goldmouth, Poker Face, Cookie, Radio -- yes sir, pick a plot and start digging...
answer: I'll raise you. Keeps your cholesterol down.

question: Hey, where you going? We got money on the table here!
answer: You know, Ray, I've been chewing on what you said this afternoon. I think I got a plan.

question: Are you trying to tell me after all this time you finally have a plan for busting out of here?
answer: Shh! Is that so hard to believe?

question: Don't tell me, I don't want to hear it. It's probably all fucked up, anyway.
answer: You don't want to hear it, you don't want to hear it. There's no shame in that.

question: It's too late for plans.
answer: Never thought I'd hear Ray Gibson say that. Hell with you then. You'd only slow me down anyway.

question: Hey, man, cover that shit up!
answer: Is everyone here?

question: Hey, where's Claude? I don't see Claude!
answer: Stay calm, Ray. We'll find him. Claude! Has anyone seen Claude?

question: He must still be in there.
answer: Wait for the firemen!

question: It'll be too late.
answer: You can't go in there, Ray! You'll never make it!
